Questionnaires
The first and second versions versions of the Multiphasic Sex Inventory Inventory (MSI; Nichols & Molinder, 1984 ; MSI-II; Nichols & Molinder, 2000 ) measure a number of characteristics of conventional and paraphilic sexual behaviors. Moreover, both contain a treatment readiness scale that provides an index of an individual’s receptivity to treatment. While the MSI has good psychometric properties (Seto et al., 2014 ), there are fewer studies regarding the MSI-II and its psychometric properties are less clear (Akerman & Beech, 2012 ).
The Multidimensional Inventory of Development, Sex, and Aggression (Multidimensional Inventory of Development, Sex, and Aggression (MIDSA), 2011 ) is a computerized self-assessment inventory developed to assess a range of sexual attitudes, fantasies, and behaviors to assist in clarifying intervention targets to reduce the risk of re-offending. The developers have made available extensive development data (Akerman & Beech, 2012 ), and the the scale has demonstrated acceptable psychometric properties (Seto et al., 2014 ) and contains four validity indicators.
The Clarke Sexual History Questionnaire-Revised (SHQ-R Sexual History Questionnaire-Revised (SHQ-R ; Langevin & Paitich, 2002 ) covers different aspects of of conventional and paraphilic sexuality and includes two validity indicators. While it is vulnerable to response bias, Laws et al. ( 2000 ) note that such measures can assist in a broader evaluation of sexual proclivities. Moreover, employing a test of impression management such as the Paulhus Deception Scales (PDS; Paulhus, 1999 ) can be a useful adjunct in assessing impression management response bias and, in the case of the PDS, an individual’s level of personal insight.
The Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) and subsequent versions (the most recent being the MMPI-3; Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2020 ) have been used to assess various aspects of sexuality, including paraphilic sexual behaviors (e. g., Hopkins et al., 2016 ; Van Slyke, 2018 ). This inventory has the advantage of well-researched validity scales and a lengthy history of research, making it useful for assessments assessments involving the court system (Ben-Porath, 2012 ).
Viewing Time
Viewing time (VT) measures (e. g., Abel Assessment of Sexual Interest; Abel et al., 1998 ) were developed developed to provide an objective but less intrusive assessment of sexual interests than phallometry (see below). In this approach, a test taker is shown a series of slides depicting pictures of clothed people of varying ages. Viewing time on each slide, measured beyond the test-taker’s test-taker’s awareness, as well as self-reported sexual interest are measured. Interest is measured by response delays induced by the preferred sexual content in stimuli to which the individuals are exposed, with the data-driven assumption that the test-taker will look longer at the images they find to be sexually attractive. Although some believe the weak psychometric properties of these procedures render them better used as a clinical tool than a risk assessment measure (e. g., Akerman & Beech, 2012 ), results results of a meta-analysis demonstrate moderate discrimination between groups of sexual offenders and nonsexual offenders as well as significant convergent validity with other measures assessing sexual preference (Schmidt et al., 2017 ). Amelung et al. ( 2024 ) found that VT could also be useful outside of a forensic context to distinguish individuals presenting with pedo-hebephilia (i. e., sexual interests in pre-pubescent and pubescent children) without a history history of offending.
Phallometry
Phallometry Phallometry involves the direct measurement of penile responses when individuals are exposed to auditory or visual sexual stimuli. These can vary on specific dimensions of interest (e. g., age, gender, and level of coercion). Phallometric responses are recorded as increases in either penile circumference or volume with indices reflecting differential responses to sex-typical and paraphilic themes. Phallometric measures have been well validated, although problems remain with a lack of standardization in terms of procedures and stimuli across evaluation centers. A recent meta-analysis (Mc Phail et al., 2019 ) supports the validity of phallometric testing for pedo-hebephilic propensities especially if audio and slides are used; the use of video stimuli was not supported. While concerns about the faking of test responses are well grounded and countermeasures are limited (Wilson & Miner, 2016 ), Mc Phail and colleagues stress stress that the validity of test results can be enhanced through the use of evidence-based practices and standardized procedures.
It is recommended recommended that users be trained in phallometry and familiar with its strengths and limitations because the results often carry a lot of weight (e. g., regarding access to biological children) (Association for the Treatment of Sexual Abusers, 2014 ). Furthermore, the results of such testing should never be used in isolation but rather be incorporated as part of a broader consideration consideration of assessment information.
Assessing Antisocial Tendencies
Adherence to antisocial antisocial values is associated with increased rates of nonsexual recidivism for both sexual and nonsexual offenders (e. g., Witte et al., 2006 ), and the assessment of such sentiments is generally included as part of a comprehensive evaluation of sexual abusers. In their most extreme form, antisocial tendencies are highly associated with criminal behavior, and, in their extreme, they present as psychopathy, which led Hare ( 2003 ) to develop the Psychopathy Checklist-Revised (PCL-R) Psychopathy Checklist-Revised (PCL-R) for forensic assessments. Psychopathy is characterized by a lack of empathy or conscience, manipulative behaviors, deceitfulness, along with impulsive and irresponsible behavior. The PCL-R has become widely used and accepted by forensic psychologists and the courts (Murrie et al., 2012 ). However, these authors demonstrated that the validity of PCL-R is eroded when users are not rigorously trained. Moreover, a subset of items measuring persistent and versatile criminality and and aggression (Facet 4) fared better than all other PCL-R elements.
Criminogenic values values have also been linked to an increased risk to engage in antisocial behavior. The Criminal Sentiments Scale (CSC; Andrews & Wormith, 1984 ) measures attitudes toward the justice system and the degree to which an individual is tolerant of law violations and identifies with other criminals. A modified version (Simourd, 1997 ) has been shown to be a good predictor of future involvement in nonsexual criminal activity among among sexual offenders (Witte et al., 2006 ).
Risk Assessment
Early risk assessment models models (before the mid-1990s) used unstructured professional judgment, which resulted in levels of prediction that were not much better than chance. Since the mid-1990s, tremendous strides in the development of risk assessment scales for sexual offenders have been made (Harris & Hanson, 2010 ). Bonta and Andrews ( 2017 ) summarized an important way of classifying risk factors into static versus dynamic/criminogenic factors, with static factors being historical/demographic factors that do not change over time (e. g., criminal history) and dynamic/criminogenic factors being those that can change and impact recidivism (e. g., sexual preoccupation levels). Not surprisingly, it is easier to gain inter-rater reliability on static tools, as they are based on file review with factors that that are either present or absent or have an objective response. Dynamic Dynamic tools require intensive training on the part of the administrator in combination with the use of structured professional judgment in scoring the responses.
In using any of the risk scales that include dynamic factors, assessors must be mindful of the potential for deceit in the individuals being assessed in their efforts to obtain a favorable evaluation. As noted earlier, Association for the Treatment of Sexual Abusers ( 2014 ) practice guidelines stress the need to include diverse, independent sources of information; doing so will greatly increase the validity of the scores obtained on risk assessment scales. If such information is lacking, a note to this effect should be made as a limitation of the assessment.
Static Measures
Globally, the Static-99R (Hanson & Thornton, 2000 ) is the most commonly used and researched actuarial scale for assessing sexual risk potential (Helmus et al., 2022 ). The obtained score on this scale is compared with that of a large database of offenders from several countries, and the sexual sexual recidivism rates for those with a similar score can be assessed, predicting recidivism up to 10 years after release release into the community. Based on extensive research, the likelihood of recidivism decreases with time spent being offense-free in the community, and the Static-99R allows for an alteration of the original score based on time being offense-free in the community during those 10 years (Hanson et al., 2018 ). The Static-99R Static-99R has been validated with many cultural groups and across several countries, but some caution needs to be exercised when using it (Phenix et al., 2016 ) given that risk assessment tools can perform less well with certain cultural groups (e. g., Indigenous offenders in Canada; Haag et al., 2016 ).
The Sex Offender Risk Appraisal Guide (SORAG; Quinsey et al., 2006 ) is also a widely used actuarial scale. The SORAG items include considerations of an individual’s offense history, school adjustment adjustment , alcohol use, and the presence of personality disorders, and it incorporates the PCL-R score among other factors. The obtained score score is compared to actuarially derived recidivism rates for offenders with similar scores over seven and 10 years. The Violence Risk Appraisal Guide-Revised (VRAG-R; Rice et al., 2013 ) may be employed to assess the risk of general and sexual violence and may be used in place of the SORAG.
Since its introduction in the mid-1990s, the Minnesota Sex Offender Screening Tool (MnSOST; Epperson et al., 1995 ) and its most recent version (the MnSOST-4; Duwe, 2019 ) have been widely used actuarial tools in screening sex offenders to prioritize them for sex offender programs and predicting level of risk, thereby helping to inform the level of community supervision required (Duwe, 2019 ).
Dynamic/Criminogenic Measures
Hanson et al. ( 2007 ) developed the Stable-2007, a standardized, empirically validated dynamic risk risk assessment measure that includes 13 dynamic risk factors associated with sexual recidivism (e. g., significant social influences, capacity for relationship stability, emotional identification with children). It can be used in conjunction with the Static-99R to determine risk, program priority, and treatment goals. A meta-analysis indicated that the Stable-2007 predicts recidivism on its own and adds predictive accuracy to the Static-99R (Brankley et al., 2021 ).
Tools Using Both Static and Dynamic Risk Factors
The Violence Risk Scale Violence Risk Scale : Sex Offender Version (VRS: SO; Olver et al., 2007 , 2018 ) contains seven static and 17 dynamic risk factors designed to assess sexual risk, assist in treatment planning, and identify changes in risk as a result of treatment or other reasons. VRS: SO scores have been been found to to predict sexual recidivism (Olver et al., 2007 ).
